00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserFormulaUpToConstant.pl - implements formulas "plus a constant".
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file implements the FormulaUpToConstant object, which is
00024 a formula that is only unique up to a constant (i.e., this is
00025 an anti-derivative). Students must include the "+C" as part of
00026 their answers, but they can use any (single-letter) constant that
00027 they want, and it doesn't have to be the one the professor used.
00028 
00029 To use FormulaWithConstat objects, load this macro file at the
00030 top of your problem:
00031 
00032     loadMacros("parserFormulaUpToConstant.pl");
00033 
00034 then create a formula with constant as follows:
00035 
00036     $f = FormulaUpToConstant("sin(x)+C");
00037 
00038 Note that the C should NOT already be a variable in the Context;
00039 the FormulaUpToConstant object will handle adding it in for
00040 you.  If you don't include a constant in your formula (i.e., if
00041 all the variables that you used are already in your Context,
00042 then the FormulaUpToConstant object will add "+C" for you.
00043 
00044 The FormulaUpToConstant should work like any normal Formula,
00045 and in particular, you use $f->cmp to get its answer checker.
00046 
00047     ANS($f->cmp);
00048 
00049 Note that the FormulaUpToConstant object creates its own private
00050 copy of the current Context (so that it can add variables without
00051 affecting the rest of the problem).  You should not notice this
00052 in general, but if you need to access that context, use $f->{context}.
00053 E.g.
00054 
00055     Context($f->{context});
00056 
00057 would make the current context the one being used by the
00058 FormulaUpToConstant, while
00059 
00060     $f->{context}->variables->names
00061 
00062 would return a list of the variables in the private context.
00063 
00064 To get the name of the constant in use in the formula,
00065 use
00066 
00067     $f->constant.
00068 
00069 If you combine a FormulaUpToConstant with other formulas,
00070 the result will be a new FormulaUpToConstant object, with
00071 a new Context, and potentially a new + C added to it.  This
00072 is likely not what you want.  Instead, you should convert
00073 back to a Formula first, then combine with other objects,
00074 then convert back to a FormulaUpToConstant, if necessary.
00075 To do this, use the removeConstant() method:
00076 
00077     $f = FormulaUpToConstant("sin(x)+C");
00078     $g = Formula("cos(x)");
00079     $h = $f->removeConstant + $g;  # $h will be "sin(x)+cos(x)"
00080     $h = FormulaUpToConstant($h);  # $h will be "sin(x)+cos(x)+C"
00081 
00082 The answer evaluator by default will give "helpful" messages
00083 to the student when the "+ C" is left out.  You can turn off
00084 these messages using the showHints option to the cmp() method:
00085 
00086     ANS($f->cmp(showHints => 0));
00087 
00088 One of the hints is about whether the student's answer is linear
00089 in the arbitrary constant.  This test requires differentiating
00090 the student answer.  Since there are times when that could be
00091 problematic, you can disable that test via the showLinearityHints
00092 flag.  (Note: setting showHints to 0 also disables these hints.)
00093 
00094     ANS($f->cmp(showLinearityHints => 0));
00095 
00096 =cut
00097 
00098 loadMacros("MathObjects.pl");
00099 
00100 sub _parserFormulaUpToConstant_init {FormulaUpToConstant::Init()}
00101 
00102 package FormulaUpToConstant;
00103 @ISA = ('Value::Formula');
00104 
00105 sub Init {
00106   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub FormulaUpToConstant {FormulaUpToConstant->new(@_)}');
00107 }
00108 
00109 #
00110 #  Create an instance of a FormulaUpToConstant.  If no constant
00111 #  is supplied, we add C ourselves.
00112 #
00113 sub new {
00114   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00115   #
00116   #  Copy the context (so we can modify it) and
00117   #  replace the usual Variable object with our own.
00118   #
00119   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context)->copy;
00120   $context->{parser}{Variable} = 'FormulaUpToConstant::Variable';
00121   #
00122   #  Create a formula from the user's input.
00123   #
00124   my $f = main::Formula($context,@_);
00125   #
00126   #  If it doesn't have a constant already, add one.
00127   #  (should check that C isn't already in use, and look
00128   #   up the first free name, but we'll cross our fingers
00129   #   for now.  Could look through the defined variables
00130   #   to see if there is already an arbitraryConstant
00131   #   and use that.)
00132   #
00133   unless ($f->{constant}) {$f = $f + "C", $f->{constant} = "C"}
00134   #
00135   #  Check that the formula is linear in C.
00136   #
00137   my $n = $f->D($f->{constant});
00138   Value->Error("Your formula isn't linear in the arbitrary constant '%s'",$f->{constant})
00139     unless $n->isConstant;
00140   #
00141   #  Make a version with adaptive parameters for use in the
00142   #  comparison later on.  We could like n00*C, but already have $n
00143   #  copies of C, so remove them.  That way, n00 will be 0 when there
00144   #  are no C's in the student answer during the adaptive comparison.
00145   #  (Again, should really check that n00 is not in use already)
00146   #
00147   my $n00 = $context->variables->get("n00");
00148   $context->variables->add(n00=>'Parameter') unless $n00 and $n00->{parameter};
00149   my $n01 = $context->variables->get("n01");
00150   $context->variables->add(n01=>'Parameter') unless $n01 and $n01->{parameter};
00151   $f->{adapt} = $f + "(n00-$n)$f->{constant} + n01";
00152 
00153   return bless $f, $class;
00154 }
00155 
00156 ##################################################
00157 #
00158 #  Remember that compare implements the overloaded perl <=> operator,
00159 #  and $a <=> $b is -1 when $a < $b, 0 when $a == $b and 1 when $a > $b.
00160 #  In our case, we only care about equality, so we will return 0 when
00161 #  equal and other numbers to indicate the reason they are not equal
00162 #  (this can be used by the answer checker to print helpful messages)
00163 #
00164 sub compare {
00165   my ($l,$r) = @_; my $self = $l; my $context = $self->context;
00166   $r = Value::makeValue($r,context=>$context) unless Value::isValue($r);
00167   #
00168   #  Not equal if the student value is constant or has no + C
00169   #
00170   return 2 if !Value::isFormula($r);
00171   return 3 if !defined($r->{constant});
00172   #
00173   #  If constants aren't the same, substitute the professor's in the student answer.
00174   #
00175   $r = $r->substitute($r->{constant}=>$l->{constant}) unless $r->{constant} eq $l->{constant};
00176   $r->context($context) unless $r->context == $context;
00177 
00178   #
00179   #  Compare with adaptive parameters to see if $l + n00 C = $r for some n0.
00180   #
00181   my $adapt = $l->adapt;
00182   my $equal = Parser::Eval(sub {$adapt == $r});
00183   $self->{adapt} = $self->{adapt}->inherit($adapt);            # save the adapted value's flags
00184   $self->{adapt}{test_values} = $adapt->{test_values};         #  (these two are removed by inherit)
00185   $self->{adapt}{test_adapt} = $adapt->{test_adapt};
00186   $_[1]->{test_values} = $r->{test_values};            # save these in student answer for diagnostics
00187   return -1 unless $equal;
00188   #
00189   #  Check that n00 is non-zero (i.e., there is a multiple of C in the student answer)
00190   #  (remember: return value of 0 is equal, and non-zero is unequal)
00191   #
00192   return abs($context->variables->get("n00")->{value}) < $context->flag("zeroLevelTol");
00193 }
00194 
00195 #
00196 #  Return the {adapt} formula with test points adjusted
00197 #
00198 sub adapt {
00199   my $self = shift;
00200   return $self->adjustInherit($self->{adapt});
00201 }
00202 
00203 #
00204 #  Inherit from the main FormulaUpToConstant, but
00205 #  adjust the test points to include the constants
00206 #
00207 sub adjustInherit {
00208   my $self = shift;
00209   my $f = shift->inherit($self);
00210   delete $f->{adapt}; delete $f->{constant};
00211   foreach my $id ('test_points','test_at') {
00212     if (defined $f->{$id}) {
00213       $f->{$id} = [$f->{$id}->value] if Value::isValue($f->{$id});
00214       $f->{$id} = [$f->{$id}] unless ref($f->{$id}) eq 'ARRAY';
00215       $f->{$id} = [map {
00216     (Value::isValue($_) ? [$_->value] :
00217         (ref($_) eq 'ARRAY'? $_ : [$_]))
00218       } @{$f->{$id}}];
00219       $f->{$id} = $self->addConstants($f->{$id});
00220     }
00221   }
00222   return $f;
00223 }
00224 
00225 #
00226 #  Insert dummy values for the constants for the test points
00227 #  (These are supposed to be +C, so the value shouldn't matter?)
00228 #
00229 sub addConstants {
00230   my $self = shift; my $points = shift;
00231   my @names = $self->context->variables->variables;
00232   my $variables = $self->context->{variables};
00233   my $Points = [];
00234   foreach my $p (@{$points}) {
00235     if (scalar(@{$p}) == scalar(@names)) {
00236       push (@{$Points},$p);
00237     } else {
00238       my @P = (.1) x scalar(@names); my $j = 0;
00239       foreach my $i (0..scalar(@names)-1) {
00240         if (!$variables->{$names[$i]}{arbitraryConstant}) {
00241       $P[$i] = $p->[$j] if defined $p->[$j]; $j++;
00242     }
00243       }
00244       push (@{$Points}, \@P);
00245     }
00246   }
00247   return $Points;
00248 }

00250 ##################################################
00251 #
00252 #  Here we override part of the answer comparison
00253 #  routines in order to be able to generate
00254 #  helpful error messages for students when
00255 #  they leave off the + C.
00256 #
00257 
00258 #
00259 #  Show hints by default
00260 #
00261 sub cmp_defaults {((shift)->SUPER::cmp_defaults,showHints => 1, showLinearityHints => 1)};
00262 
00263 #
00264 #  Provide diagnostics based on the adapted function used to check
00265 #  the student's answer
00266 #
00267 sub cmp_diagnostics {
00268   my $self = shift;
00269   my $adapt = $self->inherit($self->{adapt});
00270   $adapt->{test_values} = $self->{adapt}{test_values};  # these aren't copied by inherit
00271   $adapt->{test_adapt}  = $self->{adapt}{test_adapt};
00272   $adapt->SUPER::cmp_diagnostics(@_);
00273 }
00274 
00275 #
00276 #  Make it possible to graph single-variable formulas by setting
00277 #  the arbitrary constants to 0 first.
00278 #
00279 sub cmp_graph {
00280   my $self = shift; my $diagnostics = shift;
00281   my $F1 = shift; my $F2; ($F1,$F2) = @{$F1} if (ref($F1) eq 'ARRAY');
00282   my %subs; my $context = $self->context;
00283   foreach my $v ($context->variables->variables)
00284     {$subs{$v} = 0 if ($context->variables->get($v)->{arbitraryConstant})}
00285   $F1 = $F1->inherit($F1->{adapt})->substitute(%subs)->reduce;
00286   $F2 = $F2->inherit($F2->{adapt})->substitute(%subs)->reduce;
00287   $self->SUPER::cmp_graph($diagnostics,[$F1,$F2]);
00288 }
00289 
00290 #
00291 #  Add useful messages, if the author requested them
00292 #
00293 sub cmp_postprocess {
00294   my $self = shift; my $ans = shift;
00295   $self->SUPER::cmp_postprocess($ans,@_);
00296   return unless $ans->{score} == 0 && !$ans->{isPreview};
00297   return if $ans->{ans_message} || !$self->getFlag("showHints");
00298   my $student = $ans->{student_value};
00299   my $result = Parser::Eval(sub {return $ans->{correct_value} <=> $student}); # compare encodes the reason in the result
00300   $self->cmp_Error($ans,"Note: there is always more than one possibility") if $result == 2 || $result == 3;
00301   if ($result == 3) {
00302     my $context = $self->context;
00303     $context->flags->set(no_parameters=>0);
00304     $context->variables->add(x00=>'Real');
00305     my $correct = $self->removeConstant+"n01+n00x00";    # must use both parameters
00306     $result = 1 if $correct->cmp_compare($student+"x00",{});
00307     $context->variables->remove('x00');
00308     $context->flags->set(no_parameters=>1);
00309   }
00310   $self->cmp_Error($ans,"Your answer is not the most general solution") if $result == 1;
00311   $self->cmp_Error($ans,"Your formula should be linear in the constant '$student->{constant}'")
00312     if $result == -1 && $self->getFlag("showLinearityHints") && !$student->D($student->{constant})->isConstant;
00313 }
00314 
00315 ##################################################
00316 #
00317 #  Get the name of the constant
00318 #
00319 sub constant {(shift)->{constant}}
00320 
00321 #
00322 #  Remove the constant and return a Formula object
00323 #
00324 sub removeConstant {
00325   my $self = shift;
00326   return $self->adjustInherit(main::Formula($self->substitute($self->{constant}=>0))->reduce);
00327 }
00328 
00329 #
00330 #  Override the differentiation so that we always return
00331 #  a Formula, not a FormulaUpToConstant (we don't want to
00332 #  add the C in again).
00333 #
00334 sub D {
00335   my $self = shift;
00336   $self->removeConstant->D(@_);
00337 }
00338 
00339 ######################################################################
00340 #
00341 #  This class repalces the Parser::Variable class, and its job
00342 #  is to look for new constants that aren't in the context,
00343 #  and add them in.  This allows students to use ANY constant
00344 #  they want, and a different one from the professor.  We check
00345 #  that the student only used ONE arbitrary constant, however.
00346 #
00347 package FormulaUpToConstant::Variable;
00348 our @ISA = ('Parser::Variable');
00349 
00350 sub new {
00351   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00352   my $equation = shift; my $variables = $equation->{context}{variables};
00353   my ($name,$ref) = @_; my $def = $variables->{$name};
00354   #
00355   #  If the variable is not already in the context, add it
00356   #    and mark it as an arbitrary constant (for later reference)
00357   #
00358   if (!defined($def) && length($name) eq 1) {
00359     $equation->{context}->variables->add($name => 'Real');
00360     $equation->{context}->variables->set($name => {arbitraryConstant => 1});
00361     $def = $variables->{$name};
00362   }
00363   #
00364   #  If the variable is an arbitrary constant
00365   #    Error if we already have a constant and it's not this one.
00366   #    Save the constant so we can check with it later.
00367   #
00368   if ($def && $def->{arbitraryConstant}) {
00369     $equation->Error(["Your formula shouldn't have two arbitrary constants"],$ref)
00370       if $equation->{constant} and $name ne $equation->{constant};
00371     $equation->{constant} = $name;
00372   }
00373   #
00374   #  Do the usual Variable stuff.
00375   #
00376   $self->SUPER::new($equation,$name,$ref);
00377 }
00378 
00379 1;
